moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Bc4 Nc6 4. Ng5 d5:
kind of variation of the Petrov I rarely encounter
thitho: well, you started, with this rare Ng5 :-)
moves.5. exd5 Nxd5 6. d3 h6 7. Qf3 hxg5 8. Bxd:
sounds like equalizing
thitho: I have been thinking a lot about this one and found no other possible move. I thought you wanted this to happen.
moves.9. Bxc6+ bxc6: thitho: taking with queen wouldn't have changed for a better: you would have taken back with your own queen...
moves.10. O-O Qxf3: thitho: i saw all the mess you created in my pawns, so i figured I had no choice, because your bishop is up to take g5.
moves.11... Bd6: exposing g5 for the good of the Attack on h2
moves.12... f6: g5 is not very well defended and the structure is exposed to d4
moves.13. d4 Kf7: better than any other option with castling
moves.14... Bxe5 15. Bxg5: ?! might sound like a good idea, but...
moves.15... Bxh2+ 16. Kg2: (the best: Kf1 was exposed to Bh3+)
moves.16... Be5: threatening a fast approach of the rook... but i guess white had overestimated f4
moves.17. Bc1:
Why not c3 or Nc3??
thitho: indeed, combining the rooks was necessary, but still I think the last moves were almost impossible to avoid, unless giving the quality by Rxe5.
moves.17... Be6:
viewing Bd5 and linking the rooks
thitho: patience was necessary. Rh2 was too early here.
moves.20... Rh2h1+: there is not much to do, here...
